Fig. 1 Schematic representation of the structure of (A) Ni/SiO2 and (B) NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo = 1). Fig. 2 (A) CO2-TPD profiles of SiO2, Ni/SiO2, Mo/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2. (B) CO-TPD, (C) H2-TPD profiles of Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2. Samples were pre-reduced at 500 °C for 1 h. Fig. 3 FTIR spectra of CO2 reduction on (a) Ni/SiO2 and (b) NiMo/SiO2 at the steady state. Reaction conditions: T = 350 °C, P = 1 atm, CO2/H2/Ar = 5/20/25 mL min−1, GHSV = 100 L g−1 h−1. Fig. 4 (A) FTIR spectra during the feed transition from CO2/H2/Ar to H2/Ar on Ni/SiO2 catalyst at 350 °C, (a) spectrum at steady state in the feed of CO2/H2/Ar, and spectra after the feed was switched to H2/Ar for (b) 5 min; (c) 10 min; (d) 15 min; (c) 30 min. (B) Integral band intensity as a function of time after feed was switched to H2/Ar. (C) Normalized band intensity as a function of time after the feed was switched to H2/Ar stream. Fig. 5 (A) FTIR spectra during the feed transition from CO2/H2/Ar to H2/Ar on NiMo/SiO2 catalyst at 350 °C, (a) spectrum at steady state in the feed of CO2/H2/Ar, and spectra after the feed was switched to H2/Ar for (b) 5 min; (c) 10 min; (d) 15 min; (e) 30 min. (B) Integral band intensity as a function of time after feed was switched to H2/Ar. (C) Normalized band intensity as a function of time after the feed was switched to H2/Ar stream. Fig. 6 FTIR spectra of CO2 reduction over Ni/SiO2 as a function of reaction temperature. Feed, CO2/H2/Ar = 5/20/25 mL min−1, GHSV = 100 L g−1 h−1, T = 50–350 °C. Fig. 7 FTIR spectra of CO2 reduction over NiMo/SiO2 as a function of reaction temperature. Feed, CO2/H2/Ar = 5/20/25 mL min−1, GHSV = 100 L g−1 h−1, T = 50–350 °C. Fig. 8 Dependence of intrinsic reaction rate on (A) CO2 partial pressure and (B) H2 partial pressure over Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2. Reaction condition: T = 400°C, P = 1 atm, total gas flow rate = 100 mL min−1, GHSV = 1200 L g−1 h−1, (A) H2 flow rate was fixed at 40 mL min−1, CO2 flow rate was varied from 5 to 40 mL min−1, (B) CO2 flow rate was fixed at 5 mL min−1, H2 flow rate was varied from 10 to 95 mL min−1. Dashed lines represent the 95 % confidence limits. Fig. 9 Parity plots of CO and CH4 formation rates on Ni/SiO2. Collaborative Innovation Center of Chemical Science and Engineering Key Laboratory for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Graphical abstract A combined temperature programmed desorption (TPD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy and kinetic modeling was performed to investigate the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction on Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo molar ratio of 1) and to reveal the role of MoOx in switching the product from CH4 to CO. The results of CO2, CO and H2 TPD demonstrated that the presence of MoOx enhances CO2 adsorption, facilitates CO desorption, and weakens hydrogenation ability on the Ni catalysts. The IR results indicate the reaction proceeds with the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO*, which either desorbs as CO or undergoes further hydrogenation to CH4 on both catalysts, with formate acting as a spectator in the process. Compared with Ni/SiO2, the reaction order of CO2 decreased while the order of H2 increased significantly for CO formation on NiMo/SiO2, indicating a change in the rate-determining steps. Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic modeling confirmed that the formation of CO and CH4 on Ni/SiO2 was rate-limited by desorption of CO* and hydrogenation of CO*, respectively. In contrast, on NiMo/SiO2, the formation of CO is rate-limited by hydrogenation of OH* to H2O*. These findings demonstrate that coverage of MoOx on Ni eliminates large surface Ni ensembles and creates MoOx/Ni interfacial sites, which facilitate CO2 activation, promote CO desorption and weaken hydrogenation. Consequently, the rate-determining step for CO formation shifts from CO* desorption on Ni/SiO2 to OH* hydrogenation on NiMo/SiO2, which also suppresses CH4 formation and results in CO as the dominant product on NiMo/SiO2. Keywords CO2 reduction NiMo/SiO2 Reverse water gas shift reaction Reaction mechanism Kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The ever-growing CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has caused severe environmental concerns, which makes CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) an attractive approach to address these concerns [1,2]. By reacting with renewable H2, CO2 can be transformed into various valuable products and, therefore, can theoretically achieve carbon neutrality [3]. A highly efficient catalyst is essential to activate CO2, a thermodynamically stable molecule. Among various catalysts, Ni-based catalysts are of particular interest due to their high activity for CO2 activation and low cost. Generally, CH4 is the dominant product over CO during CO2 reduction on Ni catalysts [4], and selective production of CH4 can be applicable for the power-to-gas process [5]. Compared with a relatively inert CH4, CO, in combination with renewable H2, can be used as the feedstock of many industrial processes, such as methanol production and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [6,7], and hence is a more desirable product for further conversion. Many efforts have been made to use Ni-based catalysts for converting CO2 to CO via the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) while minimizing CH4 production [8]. Various approaches, such as reducing the size of Ni [9], altering the support and preparation method [4,10], preparing bimetallic catalysts (i.e., NiCu, NiFe, NiMo, NiZn, NiAg, NiIn) [11–17], doping alkaline promoters (such as Na) [18], have been reported to be able to improve the selectivity toward CO. In addition, the presence of surface hydroxyl group or carbon species has also been demonstrated to improve CO selectivity [19,20]. Despite significant advances in improving the performance of Ni-based catalysts for catalyzing the RWGS reaction, the detailed reaction mechanism remains inconclusive. Two main reaction mechanisms have been proposed for RWGS and methanation reactions, i.e., redox (dissociative) and associative mechanism. For the redox mechanism, the CO2 is directly dissociated to O* and CO* species, which is then desorbed to produce CO or hydrogenated to CH4 [21–28]. For the associative mechanism, the H-containing intermediate species, i.e., formate (HCOO*) and carboxyl (COOH*), play a crucial role along the reaction coordinate [29–32]. The formate species can be formed through decomposition of the bicarbonate species or hydrogenation of CO2 [33,34]. There is an ongoing debate about whether the formate species first decomposes to CO*, which is subsequently hydrogenated to CH4, or if it is directly converted to CH4 without the formation of a CO* intermediate [35,36]. A number of studies have been conducted to explore the mechanism of CO2 reduction toward CO and CH4 on Ni-based catalysts [37]. Aldana et al. [35] conducted operando infrared (IR) experiments and proposed that CH4 formation on the Ni/CeZrOx catalyst proceeds through the associative mechanism (CO2 → HCOO* → CH3O* → CH4) without forming the CO* intermediate. However, Feng et al. [27], Vrijburg et al. [38], and Yan et al. [25] suggested that CO2 reduction on Ni-based catalysts proceeded via the CO* intermediate while formate only acted as a spectator. Zhao et al. [39] proposed both CO and formate intermediates contributed to CH4 formation on the mesoporous Ni/SiO2 catalyst, with the former being dominant at low temperatures (<250 °C). The different conclusions may have resulted from different catalyst components, structures, as well as operating conditions. Recently, we reported that a NiMo/SiO2 catalyst with an optimal Ni/Mo molar ratio of 1 selectively converts CO2 to CO via the RWGS reaction with high activity, in contrast to CH4 being the dominant product on Ni/SiO2 [13]. Various characterizations revealed that the partially reduced MoOx covered partially the surface of Ni, which geometrically and electronically modified the property of Ni. However, the reaction mechanism and the role of MoOx on the reaction pathway remained unclear. In this contribution, temperature-programmed desorption, in-situ infrared spectroscopy, and kinetics studies were performed to elucidate the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction toward CO and CH4 on Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts. The results demonstrated that MoOx facilitates CO2 adsorption and activation, as well as CO desorption, resulting in CO as the dominant product. IR spectroscopy and kinetics analysis showed that the reaction follows the direct dissociation pathway with CO as the key intermediate on the Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts, whereas the rate-determining step (RDS) on them differs. Moreover, Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic models with the RDS of CO* desorption to CO and CO* hydrogenation to CH4 on Ni/SiO2 and RDS of OH* hydrogenation to H2O on NiMo/SiO2 describe the reaction well. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness co-impregnation method, as described in detail in previous work [13]. Briefly, SiO2 support (Sigma-Aldrich, specific surface area = 200 m2 g−1) was impregnated with the calculated amount of aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and (NH4)6Mo7O24 at room temperature for 12 h. Note that the pH value of impregnation was not controlled. Next, the samples were dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and finally calcined at 400 °C for 4 h. The loadings of Ni and Mo are 5.0 and 8.2 wt%, respectively, resulting in a Ni/Mo molar ratio of 1. The catalysts were reduced at 500 °C for 1 h in H2 atmosphere prior to all characterizations and catalytic tests. 2.2 Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2, CO and H2 Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 was conducted on a Chemisorb 2750 (Micrometrics) equipped with a thermal conductive detector (TCD). Prior to measurement, a catalyst of 200 mg was packed in a U-shaped quartz reactor, pre-reduced at 500 °C in flowing H2 for 1 h, followed by purging with flowing He for 1 h and cooling down to room temperature in flowing He. Afterward, the sample was exposed to flowing 5 % CO2/He for 30 min to adsorb CO2, and then the gas was switched to flowing He for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed CO2. When the TCD signal was stabilized, the sample was heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. TPD of CO and H2 were conducted using the same instrument and following the same procedure. For CO-TPD, 5 % CO/He was used as the adsorption gas. For H2-TPD, 5 %H2/Ar was used as the adsorption gas and Ar was used as the carrier gas. 2.3 In-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy experiments The in-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) experiments were performed on a PerkinElmer Frontier spectrometer equipped with a DTGS detector and an in-situ transmission reaction cell (Harrick). Approximately 30 mg of catalyst was pre-reduced ex-situ at 500 °C for 1 h in H2 atmosphere. A self-supporting wafer was made and charged in the cell and then reduced in situ at 350 °C in flowing H2 for 1 h. After purging the sample with flowing Ar for 1 h, a background was recorded as the reference. The mixture of reactants (CO2/H2/Ar of 5/20/25 mL min−1) was then fed to the sample at 350 °C. When the reaction reached a steady state, an IR spectrum was recorded. Afterward, CO2 was removed from the feed immediately, while H2/Ar was still flowing (20/25 mL min−1) for 30 min, with IR spectra being recorded as a function of time. All spectra were collected by accumulating 64 scans in the range of 4000–1000 cm−1 at a resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.4 Kinetics measurement The catalytic performance was evaluated in a fix-bed quartz tubular reactor with an outer diameter of 6 mm at the atmospheric pressure [13]. A catalyst sample (40–60 mesh) was placed between two quartz wool layers in the middle of the reactor. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 500 °C for 1 h in flowing H2. The temperature was then adjusted to 400 °C, and the reactants mixture of CO2/H2/Ar was fed at a rate of 100 mL min−1. The effluent passed through a trap in ice water and a silica gel column to remove water before being analyzed by an online gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) equipped with a TCD detector and two packed columns (Porapak Q and 5A molecular sieves). The reaction was measured under differential conditions with CO2 conversion <10 % by adjusting the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV). Under such conditions, both external and internal mass transfer limitations were negligible (see Fig. S1 and Table S1). The intrinsic reaction rates were calculated in terms of mass of catalyst. 2.5 Kinetic fittings Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic models containing a sequence of elementary steps were proposed and fitted with experimental data. The fitting was performed using nonlinear regression analysis in Microsoft Excel Solver. The minimum value of the objective function, i.e., the sum of square of error (SSE), was calculated using: (1) SSE = σ 2 = ∑ i N ( y exp - y calc ) 2 SSE represents the squared residuals of difference between experimental and predicted variable y (reaction rate) of every data point, σ represents the standard deviation, and N represents the total number of experimental data. The quality of fit was evaluated by calculating the absolute mean deviations (D) using: (2) D = σ 2 N · 1 y ¯ × 100% where y ¯ is the mean value of the experimental variables. Moreover, a linear regression (y = ax, where a is the slope) was performed to evaluate the degree of agreement between the experimental and predicted data. The closer the fitted a to 1, the better agreement between the two datasets. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Brief summary of characterization results Although Ni/SiO2 produces both CH4 and CO during CO2 reduction, NiMo/SiO2 (with an optimal Ni/Mo of 1) selectively produces CO with an improved intrinsic reaction rate [13]. The detailed characterizations (N2 adsorption, XRD, H2-TPR, TEM, XPS, and FTIR of CO adsorption) of Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo = 1) catalysts have been reported previously [13]. According to those characterizations, schematic representations of Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo = 1) catalysts were drawn and shown in Fig. 1 , to facilitate understanding the structure. Briefly, reduction at 500 °C led to a complete reduction of Ni in Ni/SiO2 to the metallic state with an average Ni particle size of 18.2 nm. In contrast, the Mo species in NiMo/SiO2 was only partially reduced to MoOx, which partially covered the surface of Ni particles, leading to geometric and electronic modification of the property of Ni. The strong interactions between Ni and MoOx promote their dispersions, resulting in highly dispersed particles of Ni and/or MoOx (with an average size of 2.5 nm). Additionally, the modification of Ni by MoOx also weakens the adsorption of CO, as evidenced by barely observable CO adsorption bands in IR spectrum at room temperature [13]. 3.2 CO2-TPD, CO-TPD and H2-TPD As the adsorption and activation of CO2 is an essential step for the reduction of CO2, CO2-TPD was performed to probe this property of the Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 A, inert SiO2 support barely adsorbs CO2. Ni/SiO2 showed two desorption peaks at 97 and 154 °C, integrating to 33.0 and 50.6 μmol·g−1, respectively, which are likely related to the bicarbonate species [40,41]. Meanwhile, Mo/SiO2 showed a broad desorption peak in the range of 150–500 °C centered at 283 °C. The peak at 200–400 °C could be ascribed to the desorption of the bidentate carbonate species on the metal–oxygen pairs (Mon+–O2–) with medium adsorption strength. The quantified amount of CO2 (158.5 μmol·g−1) is much higher than that on Ni/SiO2, indicating MoOx species provide more sites for CO2 adsorption. Compared with Mo/SiO2, the CO2 desorption peak shifted to higher temperatures for bimetallic NiMo/SiO2, i.e., 200–550 °C, and can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 223, 320, and 437 °C with the corresponding CO2 amount of 26.1, 75.1, and 90.4 μmol g−1, respectively. The latter peak can be assigned to the unidentate carbonate species on the under-coordinated O2– sites [42] or MoO2CO3 species formed by the interaction of CO2 with MoO2 [43]. Note that the low-temperature CO2 desorption peaks on Ni/SiO2 were absent on NiMo/SiO2, and the amount of CO2 adsorbed and the strength of adsorption was significantly enhanced on NiMo/SiO2 compared to Mo/SiO2. These results reflect that the presence of MoOx eliminates the bare Ni sites for CO2 adsorption via covering the surface of Ni by MoOx. In turn, the presence of Ni facilitates the reduction of MoOx and creates more sites (e.g., coordinatively unsaturated Mo-O acid-base pairs, which are created by formation of vicinal oxygen vacancies upon reduction) for CO2 adsorption at the interfacial perimeter of MoOx/Ni. CO-TPD was performed to investigate the property of CO adsorption over Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2B, three overlapping CO desorption peaks at 112, 173, and 223 °C are present for Ni/SiO2. The corresponding quantified CO amounts are 41.5, 49.9, and 25.6 μmol g−1, respectively. The first peak is related to weakly adsorbed CO in the linear form, while the latter two are associated with CO with medium adsorption strength in the bridging configurations [44]. In contrast, only a weak desorption peak at a very low temperature of 78 °C was observed for NiMo/SiO2. Moreover, the amount of adsorbed CO is much smaller, only 9.2 μmol g−1. This result indicates that CO, if formed, can readily desorb from the surface of NiMo/SiO2 under the reaction condition of 400 °C. The significantly different CO desorption behavior also suggests that MoOx covers the Ni surface and modifies the property of Ni, resulting in the d-band center shifting away from the fermi level and thus weakening the CO adsorption [28]. Since H2 dissociation and hydrogenation play an important role in CO2 reduction, H2-TPD was also performed. As shown in Fig. 2C, Ni/SiO2 exhibits two H2 desorption peaks centered at 86 and 236 °C, corresponding to desorbed H2 of 7.1 and 7.4 μmol/g, respectively. The former peak can be assigned to desorption of subsurface NiHx or weakly adsorbed H2, whereas the latter broad peak may be composed the H desorption from Ni terrace, step, and corner sites [45]. In contrast, NiMo/SiO2 only shows the low temperature peak at 83 °C with a much weaker intensity (2.7 μmol/g). No obvious H desorption from the surface of typical Ni particles can be observed. Such significant difference in turn reflects the MoOx covers most of the surface Ni ensembles and thus weakens the H2 dissociation and hydrogenation ability, which may inhibit over-hydrogenation toward CH4 during CO2 reduction. 3.3 In-situ FTIR In-situ FTIR of CO2 reduction was performed to investigate the key intermediates involved in the reaction and the likely reaction mechanism. The reaction was carried out at 350 °C in a stream of CO2/H2/Ar (5/20/25 mL/min). Fig. 3 compares the FTIR spectra of Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts when the reaction reached steady state after 30 min reaction. Reference experiments carried out in a fixed-bed reactor under identical conditions confirmed that the reaction has reached the steady state after 30 min reaction on both Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts, since both CO2 conversion and CO selectivity are constant after 20 min reaction (see Fig. S2). Distinct IR features were observed between the two catalysts. The band of gaseous CH4 at 3016 cm−1 is much stronger with the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, whereas the gaseous CO at 2170 and 2115 cm−1 is much stronger with NiMo/SiO2, confirming that the former is more selective for methanation while the latter is more selective for RWGS reaction. Strong carbonyl (CO*) bands at 1800–2100 cm−1 are present for Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Specifically, the bands at 2024, 1924 and 1850 cm−1 can be attributed to the CO* species chemisorbed in linear, bridging, and 3-fold coordinated configurations, respectively [38]. The former band is likely related with CO* on defect sites with low coordination and the latter two are associated with CO* on close packed terrace sites or large Ni ensembles with high coordination [46]. In contrast, all these CO* bands are barely observable for NiMo/SiO2. Comparing the presence of both linear and bridging CO* in FTIR during CO2 reduction at 400 °C on Ni/SiO2 catalysts with similar Ni sizes of 2–3 nm [39], we conclude that the modification of Ni by MoOx instead of Ni size is the main reason accounting for significant inhibition of CO* on NiMo/SiO2. This result in turn reflects partial coverage of Ni surface by MoOx, which eliminate large Ni ensembles and create MoOx/Ni interfacial sites, leading to very weakly binding of CO. This result is also consistent with CO-TPD, FTIR of CO adsorption [13] and DFT calculations [28], indicating that CO* readily desorbs from the surface once it is formed on NiMo/SiO2. In addition, neither formate (HCOO*) nor carbonate (CO3*) was observable on Ni/SiO2 in the range of 1350–1800 cm−1, indicating that these species may not be significant under the reaction conditions. In contrast, two weak and broad bands at 1730 and 1540 cm−1 are present on the NiMo/SiO2 catalyst, which may be relating with the vibration of ν(C=O) and νas(OCO) for the bidentate formate species [47,48] formed on MoOx away from the MoOx/Ni interface. These distinctive IR features reflect the very different surface properties of Ni and MoOx/Ni of these two catalysts. We note that carboxyl species (COOH*) was also absent in both spectra, likely due to its low amount and short lifetime [49]. To probe which surface species is the key intermediate involved in the reaction, the CO2 feed was turned off transiently from the steady state of the reaction while H2/Ar was still flowing. The IR spectra were recorded with time to track the changes in the intermediates. These changes will help to evaluate the role each intermediate played and identify the spectators in the process. The IR spectra of this transient change on Ni/SiO2 are shown in Fig. 4 A, with the integral band intensities of different species shown in Fig. 4B. To better visualize the decreasing rates of various bands, the band intensity at different times was normalized to that at the steady state and plotted as a function of time (Fig. 4C). All bands decrease with increasing time, but the rates of decrease vary. As shown in Fig. 4C, the band of CO decreases faster than that of CH4. Specifically, CO decreases to zero at 10 min, while CH4 decreases to almost zero at 30 min. Since the adsorption of CO is much stronger than CH4 on the surface, one would expect the earlier disappearance of CH4 than CO. However, the opposite trend suggests a sequential reaction of reduction of CO2 to CO followed by CO hydrogenation to CH4, confirming that the surface CO* is a key intermediate for both formations of CO and CH4 [13,19]. Among different carbonyl species, the rate of decrease follows the order of linear CO* (2024 cm−1) > bridging CO* (1924 cm−1) > 3-fold CO* (1850 cm−1), in good agreement with their relative stability on the Ni surface. We note that the relative band intensity of gaseous CO matches more closely with linear CO* at 2024 cm−1 than other CO* bands, which may suggest the linear CO* is likely to desorb and form CO while other CO* are more likely to be hydrogenated to CH4. When CO2 was turned off from the stream at the steady state on NiMo/SiO2, the band of CO decreased immediately while the band of CH4 kept constant in the initial 10 min and then decreased with increasing time (Fig. 5 A and B). The normalized band intensity relative to that at the steady state clearly shows that CH4 decreased lately than CO (Fig. 5C). However, the bands of formates remained stable throughout 30 min, indicating that the formates (likely stayed away from the MoOx/Ni interfacial perimeter sites) are the spectators during the reaction. These trends suggest that CO is formed through direct dissociation of CO2 or carboxyl species (which has not been observed), and CH4 is formed through further hydrogenation of CO. To further identify the likely intermediates during CO2 reduction, another set of IR experiments was performed. The reaction temperature was increased stepwise from 50 to 350 °C with CO2/H2/Ar at 5/20/25 mL/min. As shown in Fig. 6 , for Ni/SiO2, two bands at 1630 and 1390 cm−1 assignable to νas(OCO) and νs(OCO) of bicarbonate (HCO3*) species were present at 50 °C [50–52] and then disappeared when the temperature was increased to 100 °C. While formate (νas(OCO) at 1590 cm−1 and δ(CH) at 2961 cm−1) emerged at 100 °C, suggesting the decomposition of bicarbonate to formate [53]. In the meantime, bands of CO* (ν(CO) at 2060, 2038, 1908 and 1843 cm−1) also emerged at this temperature. This result suggests the formation of formate and CO* may follow independent pathways. In addition, the much stronger linear CO* band at 2060 and 2038 cm−1 than bridging CO* band implies that direct dissociation of CO2 is more favorable on the defect sites than on the closed-packed sites [54,55]. The intensities of both formate and CO* bands continued to increase when the temperature was increased to 150 °C. Further increasing temperature resulted in a decay of formate and a continued increase of CO*. Tiny amount of CH4 was produced at 200 °C. In comparison, gaseous CO was produced at a temperature >250 °C, indicating that hydrogenation of CO* to CH4 has a lower activation barrier than the desorption of CO* to CO on Ni/SiO2. The bands of CH4, CO and CO* continued to increase with temperature up to 350 °C, while formate bands decreased and disappeared at 350 °C. These trends did not allow us to conclude whether formate was an intermediate or a spectator for CH4/CO formation. To uncover the origin of CO*, we performed an additional IR experiment at 350 °C. The reduced sample was purged by Ar (50 mL/min) for 4 h to ensure no residual H2 in the cell and no H* on the surface of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. S3, once the gas was switched to CO2/Ar (5/45 mL/min), strong CO* bands at 2030, 1922 and 1840 cm−1 emerged immediately, confirming the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO* on the Ni surface. The CO* bands grew in intensity gradually with prolonged exposure to CO2, without CH4 being detected. However, once the gas was switched to H2/Ar (5/45 mL), the CO* band increased and CH4 appeared immediately, indicating enhanced CO2 dissociation and hydrogenation of CO* to CH4. Increasing the exposure time to H2/Ar, the bands of CH4 and CO* reached their maximum and then decreased gradually, indicating the conversion of CO* to CH4. The temperature-programmed reaction from 50 to 350°C was also performed on the NiMo/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 7 ). Different from that on Ni/SiO2, no observable band was present on NiMo/SiO2 at 50 °C, which is likely a result of few surface OH groups (see Fig. S4) for the formation of the bicarbonate species. Broad bands at 1730 and 1540 cm−1, likely related to ν(C=O) and νas(OCO) of bidentate formate [47,48], started to emerge at 100 °C. These bands increased slightly with increasing temperature and remained almost constant at 350 °C when purged with H2 (see Fig. 5), ruling out formate as a significant intermediate for CO formation. The bands corresponding to CO* were barely observable across the entire temperature range, and CO was started to be observable at 250 °C, lower than that on Ni/SiO2, confirming the facile desorption of CO* from NiMo/SiO2. The CH4 band was tiny and only appeared at ≥250 °C, which is higher than that on Ni/SiO2, reflecting the low methanation activity. To further investigate the reaction pathway, we performed an additional IR experiment by sequentially feeding CO2 and H2 at 350 °C (Fig. S5). Prior to introducing CO2, the in situ reduced sample was purged by Ar (50 mL/min) for 4 h to ensure no residual H2 in the cell and H* on the surface of NiMo/SiO2. Upon feeding CO2, CO was produced without CO* observable, indicating the formed CO* readily desorbs from the surface. Only a small amount of CH4 was produced when the gas was shifted to H2. These results indicate that direct CO2 dissociation is likely the dominant path for CO formation. 3.4 Kinetics 3.4.1 Reaction orders To further explore the reaction mechanism on the Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2, the apparent reaction orders of H2 and CO2 were measured at 400°C under differential conditions, i.e., CO2 conversion <10 %. Under such conditions, both CO and CH4 are formed on Ni/SiO2, while only CO is formed on NiMo/SiO2. Thus, the apparent orders for both CO and CH4 were determined to track their likely reaction pathways. Standard deviations of repeated experiments were calculated for error analyses and 95 % confidence limits were adopted to ensure the reliability of fitting results (see details of error analysis in supplementary materials) [56]. The fitting results are given as data ± uncertainty, and the range of 95 % confidence intervals is plotted as dashed lines (Fig. 8 ). The difference between the fitting results of Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts is much larger than their uncertainties, confirming that the difference is originated from the catalytic activity rather than error. As shown in Fig. 8, the CO formation rate over Ni/SiO2 depends on CO2 partial pressure with an order of 0.40 ± 0.01, while it depends on H2 partial pressure with a near ly zero order (n = −0.03 ± 0.02). This result reflects that the formation of CO is strongly dependent on the coverage of CO2-derived species due to its weak adsorption property of CO2 on the surface of Ni (see Fig. 2A). The fact that CO formation was minimally affected by H2 suggests that either the surface is saturated with H2-derived species, or the H adatom does not play a role in the RDS for CO formation. Notably, the FTIR results showed a significant amount of CO* on the Ni surface, ruling out surface saturation by H-derived species, since CO*, H* and the likely COOH*, HCOO* and other species may compete for the same atop, bridge and hollow Ni sites [28]. Additionally, the zero-order dependence on H2 further excludes the contribution of H2-derived species (H*, HCOO*, COOH*) to CO formation. Instead, the formation of CO likely formed from direct dissociation of CO2* to CO*, which is then followed by desorption. This is supported by the in-situ FTIR experiments of feeding CO2 without H2 to clean reduced Ni/SiO2 (Fig. S3), which showed CO* was immediately formed. In contrast, the trend for CH4 formation is quite different. CH4 formation is nearly independent of CO2 partial pressure, with an order of nearly zero (n = 0.01 ± 0.02), while it depends on H2 partial pressure with an order of 0.38 ± 0.03. This result indicates the surface is saturated with CO2-derived species (likely CO*), and H participates in the RDS for CH4 formation. These findings are consistent with the apparent activation energy of 147.3 kJ mol−1 for CO formation and 49.6 kJ mol−1 for CH4 formation on Ni/SiO2 (measured in 360–420 °C and atmospheric pressure under differential conditions) [13], suggesting the formation of CO is limited by its desorption, whereas the formation of CH4 limited by further hydrogenation steps. Different reaction orders for CO formation are observed over NiMo/SiO2. Compared to Ni/SiO2, the CO2 order is slightly decreased to 0.35 ± 0.02, while the H2 order increases significantly to 0.61 ± 0.02 (Fig. 8). This result indicates MoOx enhances CO2 adsorption (see Fig. 2A), resulting in higher coverage of CO2* species. In contrast, the partial covering of the Ni surface by MoOx reduces the number of accessible Ni sites and modifies the property of the available Ni sites for H2 adsorption and dissociation (see Fig. 2C), resulting in lower coverage of the H2-derived species. The much higher reaction order for H2 compared to CO2 suggests that the RDS for CO formation likely involves the H2-derived species. Moreover, the reduced H2 dissociation activity also limits further hydrogenation of the surface CO* species to CH4, resulting in CO as the dominant product. 3.4.2 Kinetic models To validate the reaction mechanism proposed based on FTIR results and reaction order analysis, a Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model including a sequence of elementary steps was developed and fitted to the experimental data. Note that the kinetics were performed at 400 °C while the FTIR experiments were carried out up to 350 °C due to temperature limitation of the in situ cell. This slight difference in reaction temperature is not expected to change the conclusion, since the experiments at 350 and 400 °C under otherwise identical reaction conditions (P = 1 atm, CO2/H2/Ar = 5/20/25 mL/min, GHSV = 1000 L g−1 h−1) in a fixed-bed reactor showed similar selectivities on each catalyst at different reaction temperature (Fig. S6), i.e., CO and CH4 on Ni/SiO2 while dominant CO on NiMo/SiO2. According to FTIR results, the reduction of CO2 to CO on the Ni/SiO2 catalyst was assumed to proceed via the direct dissociation mechanism. Due to linear CO* (IR band of 2024 cm−1 and the first desorption peak in CO-TPD) binds weakly and readily desorbs, while the bridging and multi-bonding CO* (IR bands of 1924 and 1850 cm−1 and likely the second and third desorption peaks in CO-TPD) bind strongly and are more likely to be hydrogenated into CH4, we distinguished the weak and strong binding Ni sites for CO adsorption as ° and †, respectively. These two sites physically correspond to the defect and close-packed terrace sites [57], which favor CO adsorption in linear and (2- and 3-fold) bridging form, respectively [20]. A similar distinction was used by Jiménez and co-workers [58]. Consequently, the formation rate of CO is limited by its desorption from the site °, and CO° may transfer to CO† for further hydrogenation. CH4 formation on the Ni surface may proceed via either direct dissociation of CO* followed by hydrogenation of C* to CHx*, or hydrogenation of CO* to CHO* and followed by decomposition to CH* and then sequential hydrogenation to CH4 [39]. The CO* dissociation step is suggested as the RDS for the former pathway [22], implying that the reaction rate is minimally affected by the partial pressure of H2. However, this contradicts the measured H2 reaction order of 0.38 for CH4 formation. Thus, the reaction is more likely following the latter pathway, where the RDS is the hydrogenation of CO* to CHO* [58]. The likely elementary steps for the reduction of CO2 to CO and CH4 over Ni/SiO2 catalyst are summarized in Table 1 . At the pseudo steady state of the reaction, the elementary steps 8 (desorption of weakly adsorbed CO°) and 9 (hydrogenation of strongly adsorbed CO†) were assumed to be the RDS for CO and CH4 formation, respectively, while other steps were quasi-equilibrated. The formation rates of CO (rCO) and CH4 (rCH4) can then be derived using a Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model (see the details in Supplementary material): (3) r CO = k 8 ∙ K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 ∙ P C O 2 0.5 K 7 ∙ K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 + K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 ∙ P C O 2 0.5 + K 5 K 6 K 7 2 ∙ P C O 2 0.5 + K 7 ∙ K 2 K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 ∙ P H 2 0.5 (4) r C H 4 = k 9 ∙ K 1 0.5 ∙ k 17 ∙ ( K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 ) 0.5 ∙ ( P C O 2 ∙ P H 2 ) 0.5 ( k 17 + K 3 K 4 k 9 k 17 ∙ P C O 2 0.5 + k 17 ∙ ( K 3 K 4 k 17 k 9 ) 0.5 ∙ P C O 2 0.5 + k 17 ∙ K 1 0.5 ∙ P H 2 0.5 ) 2 where ki represents the forward rate constant and Ki represents the equilibrium constant of step i. The parity plots (Fig. 9 ) show that the equations (3) and (4) predicted CO and CH4 formation rates agree well with the measured rates, with D = 6.3 % and a = 0.980, confirming the proposed model with RDS was reasonable. The fitted (lumped) parameters with standard deviations are reported in Table 2 . The fitted k8 (196.5 ± 1.95 μmol g−1 s−1) is lower than k9 (233.6 ± 1.08 μmol·g−1 s−1), reflecting that the hydrogenation of CO† to CH4 is more favorable over the desorption of CO°. Note that the fitted k17 (372.7 ± 4.67 μmol g−1 s−1) is much higher than k8 and k9, which implies hydrogenation of formed O* on Ni is facile. The fitted K7 (2.147 ± 0.02) is much higher than 1, implying the transition of weakly adsorbed to CO° to strongly adsorbed CO† is favorable at 400 °C. Also, this result indicates the majority of weakly adsorbed CO° is originated from CO2 dissociation on the ° site rather than the transition from CO†, which is consistent with the DFT simulation that showed CO2 dissociation is more readily on the defect site than on closed packed site [54,59]. According to the characterization results in current and previous work [13], NiMo/SiO2 has only one dominant type of site, i.e., MoOx/Ni interfacial perimeter site (denoted as §). This site binds CO weakly, making CO the dominant product. CH4 formation is negligible under differential conditions and, therefore, was excluded from kinetic modeling. In addition, the FTIR results showed that CO is formed through direct dissociation of CO2 although the RDS remains unclear. To address this, a sequence of elementary steps was proposed (Table 3 ), and each step was evaluated as the potential RDS to derive the rate equations according to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model (see details in the Supplementary material). The parity plots comparing the measured and model-predicted CO formation rates are displayed in Fig. 10 and Fig. S7. As shown in the parity plots (Fig. S7A and B), the assumptions of CO2 adsorption and dissociation as the RDS resulted in a poor fit (D > 20 %) between the measured CO formation rates and predicted rates. This result is consistent with the relatively low CO2 apparent reaction order of 0.35, suggesting that enhanced CO2 adsorption and dissociation at the MoOx/Ni interfacial site are unlikely to be the RDS. Assuming CO desorption as the RDS resulted in a better fit (D = 12 %, a = 0.995, Fig. S7C) but contradicts the observation that CO readily desorbs from the surface of NiMo/SiO2 (Fig. 2B) and therefore, its desorption cannot be the RDS. Instead, the high H2 reaction order (0.61) indicates the involvement of H-containing species in the RDS. The model assuming H2 dissociation as the RDS (Fig. 10A) shows poor agreement between the measured and predicted CO formation rates (D = 28 %, a = 0.933). Similarly, assuming hydrogenation of O§ to OH§ as the RDS (Fig. 10B) also provides a poor fit (D = 26 %, a = 0.944). These results allow us to exclude the possibility of H2 dissociation and O§ hydrogenation to OH§ as the RDS. In contrast, a good agreement between the predicted and measured rates can be achieved when the hydrogenation of OH§ to H2O§ and H2O§ desorption is assumed to be the RDS (Fig. 10C and D). Considering desorption is an entropy-driven process, the H2O desorption is unlikely to be the RDS. Hence, the hydrogenation of OH§ to H2O§ is the most likely RDS, and it provides the best fit (D = 16 %, a = 0.979). This conclusion is further supported by recent DFT results for CO2 reduction at the Mo3O5/Ni(111) interface [28]. With the assumption of hydrogenation of OH§ to H2O§ as the RDS, the formation rate of CO (rCO) can be derived using a Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic mode: (5) r CO = k 6 ∙ K 1 K 2 K 3 K 4 K 5 ∙ P H 2 P C O 2 P H 2 O ( 1 + K 1 K 2 · P C O 2 + K 3 0.5 · P H 2 0.5 + 1 K 4 · P CO + 1 K 7 ∙ P H 2 O + K 1 K 2 K 4 K 5 · P C O 2 P CO + K 1 K 2 K 3 0.5 K 4 K 5 ∙ P C O 2 P H 2 0.5 P CO ) 2 The fitted (lumped) parameters are listed in Table 4 . The three orders of magnitude higher of the fitted k6 (187.2 ± 5.7 mmol·g−1·s−1) relative to that of RDS on Ni/SiO2 reflects a much higher CO2 reduction rate on NiMo/SiO2. The relatively small values of K4 −1 and K7 −1 indicate the desorption of CO and H2O are facile. We note that the proposed kinetic models show that H2O does not and does play a role on the reaction rate over Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2, respectively. To verify the role of H2O revealed in the kinetic models, the experiments of co-feeding H2O were performed. Specifically, H2O vapor (5 mL/min) was co-fed with reactants (CO2/H2/H2O/Ar = 5/20/5/20 mL/min) at 400 °C and GHSV of 1000 L g−1 h−1. As shown in Fig. 11 , co-feeding H2O (H2O/CO2 = 1) has little effect on both CO2 conversion and CH4/CO yield over Ni/SiO2, which confirms that the formation of CO and CH4 are not rate limited by H2O formation related steps but by desorption and hydrogenation of CO* steps, respectively. In contrast, the presence of H2O significantly suppressed CO2 conversion and CO yield over NiMo/SiO2, which verifies the formation of CO is rate limited by H2O* formation. In summary, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic model, with different RDSs on Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2, describes the experimental data well and validates the reaction mechanism derived from the FTIR results and reaction order analysis. Moreover, the proposed mechanism is in good agreement with the recent DFT study on CO2 reduction over Ni(111) and Mo3O5/3 × 3 Ni(111) interface [28], providing additional validation. These findings emphasize that the MoOx/Ni interfacial perimeter site facilitates both the adsorption and activation of CO2, as well as desorption of CO, causing a shift of RDS from CO* desorption to site regeneration (i.e., OH* hydrogenation to H2O) for CO formation. This shift enhances the RWGS reaction relative to methanation, leading to an improved RWGS performance compared to the bare Ni catalyst. 4 Conclusions The reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction on Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo = 1) catalysts has been studied using a combination of TPD, IR spectroscopy and kinetic modeling. The results of CO2, CO, and H2 TPD demonstrated that MoOx enhances CO2 adsorption, facilitates CO desorption, and weakens hydrogenation ability on the Ni catalysts. FTIR results indicated the reaction proceeds through the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO*, which then either desorbs as CO or undergoes further hydrogenation to CH4 on both catalysts, with formate being a spectator in the process. Compared to Ni/SiO2, the reaction order with respect to CO2 decreased, while the order with respect to H2 significantly increased for CO formation on NiMo/SiO2, indicating a change in the rate-determining steps. Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic modeling confirmed that the formations of CO and CH4 on Ni/SiO2 are rate-limited by the desorption of CO* and the hydrogenation of CO*, respectively. In contrast, on NiMo/SiO2, the formation of CO is rate-limited by the hydrogenation of OH* to H2O*, and no CH4 is produced under differential conditions. These results suggest that the MoOx (Ni/Mo = 1) eliminates large surface Ni ensembles, preventing the formation of strongly bound CO* and inhibiting further hydrogenation. On the other hand, the MoOx/Ni interfacial sites that are created facilitate efficient adsorption and activation of CO2. As a result, the rate-determining step shifts from CO* desorption on Ni/SiO2 to site regeneration (i.e., OH* hydrogenation) for CO formation on NiMo/SiO2, which also reduces CH4 formation and results in CO as the dominant product. coredata.dc:description: A combined temperature programmed desorption (TPD), infrared (IR) spectroscopy and kinetic modeling was performed to investigate the reaction mechanism of CO2 reduction on Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 (Ni/Mo molar ratio of 1) and to reveal the role of MoOx in switching the product from CH4 to CO. The results of CO2, CO and H2 TPD demonstrated that the presence of MoOx enhances CO2 adsorption, facilitates CO desorption, and weakens hydrogenation ability on the Ni catalysts. The IR results indicate the reaction proceeds with the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO*, which either desorbs as CO or undergoes further hydrogenation to CH4 on both catalysts, with formate acting as a spectator in the process. Compared with Ni/SiO2, the reaction order of CO2 decreased while the order of H2 increased significantly for CO formation on NiMo/SiO2, indicating a change in the rate-determining steps. Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic modeling confirmed that the formation of CO and CH4 on Ni/SiO2 was rate-limited by desorption of CO* and hydrogenation of CO*, respectively. In contrast, on NiMo/SiO2, the formation of CO is rate-limited by hydrogenation of OH* to H2O*. These findings demonstrate that coverage of MoOx on Ni eliminates large surface Ni ensembles and creates MoOx/Ni interfacial sites, which facilitate CO2 activation, promote CO desorption and weaken hydrogenation. Consequently, the rate-determining step for CO formation shifts from CO* desorption on Ni/SiO2 to OH* hydrogenation on NiMo/SiO2, which also suppresses CH4 formation and results in CO as the dominant product on NiMo/SiO2.

coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insights into the selectivity switch in CO2 reduction over Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/SiO2 catalysts: A combined study of temperature programmed desorption, infrared spectroscopy and kinetics
